article.title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
funding: MRC Versus Arthritis Centre for Musculoskeletal Ageing Research [Grant Numbers MR/P021220/1 and MR/R502364/1]
National Institute for Health Research Nottingham Biomedical Research Centre
article.abstract: In this study, we report a microfluidic device for the whole-life culture of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans that allows the scoring of animal survival and health measures.

sections.introduction: Aging is a significant risk factor for a broad range of diseases including neurodegenerative disorders, diabetes and cancer1–5. With the growing aging population, the socioeconomic burden attributed with age-associated diseases is staggering and development of therapies that promote healthy aging is imperative.
sections.methods: All animals were cultured on 60 mm petri dishes containing nematode growth medium (NGM) at 20 °C before loading into the microfluidic chamber.
sections.results: We demonstrated that C. elegans can be effectively maintained in our NemaLife microfluidic device across its lifespan without using chemicals (progeny-blocking drugs, antibacterial agents, antifungal compounds, etc.) in an environment that recapitulates longevity on agar plates.
sections.discussion: The capacity for manual injections of fluids and food enables investigator control over feeding conditions or introduced drugs.

article.insights_summary: We report a microfluidic device for the whole-life culture of C. elegans that allows the scoring of animal survival and health measures. The device features a micropillar arena, sieve channels, and ports for feeding and introducing reagents. We demonstrate that C. elegans can be effectively maintained in the device across its lifespan without using chemicals.
article.acknowledgments: This work was partially supported by funding from NIH, NASA, NSF CAREER, BBSRC, MRC Versus Arthritis Centre for Musculoskeletal Ageing Research, and National Institute for Health Research Nottingham Biomedical Research Centre.
